introduction.overview: Unit 2 has equipped you with tools for creating polished, professional English texts. You've studied the grammatical and textual features that ensure clarity at the sentence level (agreement, parallelism) and coherence across longer passages (punctuation, cohesion). These skills are essential for translators who must produce target-language texts that read naturally and professionally.
objectives: Review complex agreement patterns that challenge non-native speakers
Consolidate understanding of parallel structures and their rhetorical effects
Synthesize knowledge of advanced punctuation strategies
Master the use of cohesion devices for creating well-structured texts

sections.heading: Week 6: Subject-Verb Agreement
sections.content: While basic subject-verb agreement is straightforward, challenging contexts create opportunities for error. Collective nouns (team, committee, government) can take singular or plural verbs depending on whether the group acts as a unit or as individuals. Indefinite pronouns vary: some are always singular (everyone, nobody), some always plural (both, many), and some depend on context (none, all, some). Inverted structures (There are..., Rarely does...) and compound subjects with correlative conjunctions (either...or, neither...nor) require careful attention. In translation, these patterns don't always correspond across languages—Spanish often treats collective nouns differently than English does.
keyTakeaways: Collective nouns: singular for unity, plural for individual members
Indefinite pronouns follow specific patterns (everyone is, both are)
In 'either...or' sentences, verb agrees with the closest subject
Inverted structures still follow agreement rules (There are problems)
Agreement errors undermine credibility in professional writing

sections.heading: Week 7: Pronoun Agreement & Reference Chains
sections.content: Pronouns must agree with their antecedents in number, gender, and person, but identifying the antecedent isn't always simple. Indefinite pronouns like 'everyone' are grammatically singular but semantically plural, creating tension with the traditional 'he or she' solution. Modern professional writing increasingly uses 'they' as a singular pronoun. Beyond agreement, pronouns create reference chains that guide readers through texts. Unclear pronoun reference (ambiguous 'it,' 'this,' or 'they') forces readers to work harder and can create misunderstanding—particularly problematic in legal or technical translation where precision is essential.
keyTakeaways: Pronouns must have clear, unambiguous antecedents
Singular 'they' is now accepted in professional and academic contexts
Reference chains create cohesion by connecting ideas across sentences
Vague 'this,' 'it,' and 'which' can create ambiguity
In translation, managing reference across languages requires strategic thinking

sections.heading: Week 8: Parallel Structures
sections.content: Parallelism means using the same grammatical structure for coordinate elements (items in a list, parts of a comparison, elements joined by correlative conjunctions). Parallel structures create rhythm, emphasize relationships between ideas, and make texts easier to process. Non-parallel constructions feel awkward: 'She enjoys reading, to write, and swimming' lacks the elegance of 'She enjoys reading, writing, and swimming.' Parallelism matters especially in formal contexts—academic writing, professional reports, marketing copy. For translators, maintaining parallel structures in the target language requires sometimes restructuring sentences rather than translating word-by-word.
keyTakeaways: Elements in a list must share the same grammatical structure
Correlative conjunctions (not only...but also) require parallel elements
Parallel structures enhance clarity and create rhetorical emphasis
Breaking parallelism usually signals careless writing
Translation may require restructuring to maintain parallelism in the target language

sections.heading: Week 9: Advanced Punctuation
sections.content: Punctuation does more than mark pauses—it clarifies relationships between ideas and controls pacing. Colons introduce explanations or lists and create anticipation. Semicolons connect closely related independent clauses, showing a tighter relationship than a period but maintaining independence that a comma can't provide. Dashes (em-dashes) emphasize or insert information with more drama than parentheses. Parentheses downplay information, suggesting 'by the way' material. In translation between languages with different punctuation conventions (Spanish uses more commas; English often prefers more periods for short sentences), these tools help create target texts that follow appropriate conventions while preserving meaning and emphasis.
keyTakeaways: Colons introduce and create expectation; semicolons connect related independent clauses
Dashes emphasize; parentheses downplay
Punctuation choices affect meaning, not just correctness
Overusing semicolons or dashes can feel overwrought
Different languages have different punctuation conventions and preferences

sections.heading: Week 10: Cohesion Devices
sections.content: Cohesion devices are the glue that holds texts together. Connectors (however, therefore, meanwhile) show logical relationships between sentences and paragraphs. Reference words (pronouns, demonstratives, the definite article 'the') link back to previous information. Lexical chains use related words (car → vehicle → it; doctor → physician → she) to maintain topics across sentences without repetition. Substitution (one, do so) and ellipsis (omitting repeated elements) prevent wordiness. Skilled writers use cohesion devices transparently—readers feel the text flows naturally without noticing the specific mechanisms. Translators must recreate this flow in the target language, which may require different strategies.
keyTakeaways: Connectors show relationships: addition, contrast, cause-effect, time sequence
Reference chains maintain topics without excessive repetition
Lexical cohesion uses related words to create semantic connections
Too few cohesion devices create choppy writing; too many can feel heavy-handed
Cohesion strategies vary across languages and cultures

studyTips: Review corrected exercises from weeks 6-10, understanding why errors occurred
Practice identifying cohesion devices in newspaper articles or academic abstracts
Read your own writing aloud to catch agreement errors and non-parallel structures
Analyze punctuation choices in professional texts from your field
Work with your group to create examples demonstrating proper agreement and parallelism
Compare English and Spanish texts to observe cohesion differences

introduction.overview: This group examination asks you to demonstrate mastery of the grammatical and textual features that create coherent, professional English writing. You'll analyze authentic texts, correct problematic passages, and produce polished writing that showcases your understanding of agreement, parallelism, punctuation, and cohesion.
introduction.format: Complete this exam with your assigned group (3-4 students). You have one week to complete the project. Submit one document per group with all members' names clearly listed.

tasks.title: Error Analysis and Correction
tasks.instructions: The following passage contains multiple errors related to subject-verb agreement, pronoun agreement and reference, parallel structure, and punctuation. As a group, identify and correct all errors, then explain your corrections.
tasks.passage: Every translator face unique challenges in their work. The team of translators were asked to not only complete the project quickly but also maintaining high quality. There was several issues with the source document that needed addressing. Each of the translators have their own approach to handling ambiguity—some consults reference materials extensively while others relies on instinct and experience. Neither the project manager nor the translators was satisfied with the timeline. When reviewing translations, you must check for accuracy, ensuring consistency, and that the tone is appropriate. The committee have decided to revise their guidelines however they haven't announced when this will happen. Everyone needs to make sure they proofread their work carefully, its essential for maintaining credibility.
deliverables: Provide the corrected passage with all errors fixed
Create a numbered list identifying each error type and explaining the correction
Discuss at least one error that your group debated and explain your reasoning for the final choice

tasks.title: Cohesion Analysis
tasks.instructions: Select a well-written 300-400 word passage from a professional source (article, blog post, business communication, or academic abstract in your field). Analyze how the author creates cohesion throughout the text.
deliverables: Provide the source passage with proper citation
Identify and label at least 10 cohesion devices, categorizing them (connectors, reference chains, lexical cohesion, substitution/ellipsis)
Highlight at least one effective reference chain showing how the author tracks a topic across multiple sentences
Analyze the punctuation in 3-5 complex sentences, explaining how the author's choices affect meaning or emphasis
Write a brief evaluation (150 words) of the overall cohesion: Is it effective? Too heavy-handed? Too sparse? How does it contribute to the professional tone?

tasks.title: Polished Writing Application
tasks.instructions: As a group, compose a 200-250 word professional text on one of the following topics: (a) advice for students entering translation/interpretation programs, (b) the importance of specialized knowledge in professional translation, or (c) challenges and solutions in collaborative translation projects. Your writing must demonstrate mastery of all Unit 2 concepts.
deliverables: A brief commentary (100-150 words) identifying where you deliberately applied Unit 2 concepts: point out your uses of parallel structure, your punctuation choices, your cohesion devices, and how you ensured agreement throughout

submissionGuidelines: Submit as a single document (PDF or Google Doc link)
Include all group members' full names on the first page
Use clear headings for each task
Proofread meticulously—errors in a unit about precision are particularly problematic
Due: End of Week 11 (specific date provided by instructor)

gradingCriteria.description: Your group project will be evaluated on the following criteria:

criteria.details: Accurate identification and correction of all errors; clear explanations demonstrating understanding; thoughtful discussion of debated point
Thorough identification and categorization of cohesion devices; insightful analysis of reference chains and punctuation; evaluative commentary demonstrates critical understanding
Writing is clear, professional, and error-free; deliberate application of Unit 2 concepts; effective self-reflection in commentary

introduction.message: Congratulations on completing Unit 2! You've developed a sophisticated understanding of what makes English writing clear, precise, and professional. These skills go beyond avoiding errors—they help you craft texts that guide readers smoothly through ideas and maintain credibility in professional contexts.

achievements: You can now navigate complex agreement situations with confidence
You understand how pronoun reference chains create cohesion across texts
You've mastered parallel structures and recognize their rhetorical power
You can use advanced punctuation strategically to clarify meaning and control emphasis
You can analyze and produce cohesive texts using appropriate linguistic devices

lookingAhead.message: Unit 3 explores the pragmatic dimension of English—how context, culture, and social relationships shape language choices. You'll study phrasal verbs, idiomatic expressions, and register variation, all crucial for translation work that must navigate not just linguistic but cultural differences.
preview: Phrasal verbs: their challenge for translation and strategies for mastery
Register and style variation across professional contexts
Pragmatic awareness for effective translation and localization decisions

conclusion.celebrateProgress: You've moved from studying verbs (Unit 1) to studying how entire texts work. You can now not only understand complex English structures but also produce writing that meets professional standards. This is the foundation of excellent translation work.
